blockquote.p: [Peter] Palchinsky realised [...] most real-world problems are more complex than we think. They have a human dimension, a local dimension and are likely to change as circumstances change. His method for dealing with this could be summarized as three 'Palchinsky principles': first seek out new ideas and try new things: second, when trying something new, do it on a scale where failure is survivable; third, seek out feedback and learn from your mistakes as you go along. The first principle could simply be expressed as [the evolutionary concept of] 'variation'; the third as [the evolutionary concept of] 'selection'.

div.p: from "Adapt: Why Success Always Starts with Failure"
